Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Local-level Effects of Centrally Mandated Change

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Social scientists contribute to understanding the complex dynamics of particular areas of social behavior by attending to the larger contexts in which they occur. Currently, one potentially fruitful arena for developing new theory of mandated change is the worldwide concern about the causes of differential health outcomes. Observers have noted that unprecedented resources are being poured into funding healthcare initiatives, yet serious disparities persist. Efforts to alter this situation give social scientists valuable opportunities for investigating the causal relationships in social systems at multiple interacting levels of scale. Findings from such investigations have important implications for developing new social science theory as well application in many social spheres.

In this research project, Yale University doctoral student Gabriela E. Morales, with the guidance of Dr. P. Sean Brotherton, will undertake research on one such natural experiment of planned, top-down change. It is occurring in Bolivia where the government has proposed to end health inequalities by creating an expansive new national health policy. The new policy increases low-cost, rural primary healthcare that also incorporates indigenous worldviews, including an unusual holistic model of health and well being, community decision-making, and intercultural care. This is a fascinating opportunity for social science investigation. The changes are only now underway and the smaller-scale of the Bolivian context makes intensive research feasible. The researcher will first study policy making and the training of health care providers in the capital city and then investigate local implementation of the new program in a rural district. Data will be collected using a range of social science methodologies including: semi-structured interviews, oral histories, therapeutic narratives, participant-observation, archival investigations, and document analysis. By drawing on these ethnographic methodologies, this research links large-scale processes of social change with a fine-grained analysis of implementation and on-the-ground effects. Lessons learned will useful for those concerned with many areas of planned social intervention.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research is an anthropological study of the implementation of Bolivian policies designed to tailor healthcare services to indigenous social and cultural contexts. The majority of Bolivia’s population identifies as indigenous, but has long remained marginalized — often facing discrimination and unequal access to health services. Since 2006, national government officials have partially sought to remedy these exclusions by promoting more culturally sensitive medical care and also incorporating traditional healers and midwives into clinical services. This project explores how hospital practitioners, healers, midwives, and patients are engaging with these reforms in their medical encounters. It illuminates how practices of caring for and relating to patients have been deeply entangled in shifting national norms of what constitutes “culture” and “the indigenous” over time.
    This work makes key contributions to debates concerning culturally appropriate healthcare in Bolivia but also in a variety of contexts around the world. International institutions like the World Health Organization (WHO) have moved toward policies that take into account “traditional and alternative” medical practices. In the United States, medical schools are increasingly training doctors and nurses in cultural competency. These various approaches explicitly seek to address problems of miscommunication between practitioners and patients and ensure that patients return to the hospital. Bolivia presents a unique instance of these kinds of policies being implemented at a national level. This research highlights the complexities of such interventions, which have created new possibilities for patient inclusion, but also sometimes reproduce exclusionary stereotypes and discriminatory practices.
    The researcher spent a total of twenty months conducting in-depth ethnographic and archival research in Bolivia. The first six months were based in the capital city of La Paz and involved tracing the past and present creation of health policies toward indigenous peoples. Fieldwork entailed detailed examination of policy and media archives, semi-structured interviews with state and NGO officials, and participant-observation in workshops and planning meetings. The next twelve months of the project were situated in a small, predominantly indigenous Aymara town in the Andes. Research for this phase centered on semi-structured interviews and oral histories with biomedical practitioners, traditional healers, midwives, and residents of the town about their experiences with healthcare policies. It also entailed participant-observation in the local municipal hospital, during health campaigns, and in people’s homes. The final two months of the project were spent conducting additional archival research and follow-up interviews.
    In sum, this project takes experiences of illness, medical encounters, and everyday practices of care as a lens through which to understand how people are experiencing wider policy changes. As such, it offers a window into the complexities of adapting healthcare to particular sociocultural contexts.
